utterances: I think what happens is when individuals die, we just didn't know.
After you have a death - we're one of the few medical examiners offices that routinely does toxicology tests.
But it could take as much as two or three months after an individual dies before the final toxicology's available.
And even in these 19 cases, we're saying presumed fentanyl because the circumstances of the death lead one to believe it's similar to the ones that were confirmed fentanyl.
But actually those cases of the individuals who died on Thursday, we will not have a definitive cause of death until the toxicology results are out.
Could be as much as two to three months from last Thursday.
So we're letting the public know even prior to our having confirmed that it is fentanyl just because of those very concerns.
Have you ever seen anything like this?
No.
This is the first time I've seen anything like this.
And it's very concerning, very troubling.
Dr.
Reid, thanks so much for talking to us.
Thank you so much for having us.
Dr. Michele Reid is medical director at the Detroit/Wayne County Mental Health Agency.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.

The Marine Corps' top general, Michael Hagge, flew to Iraq today to tell his troops they should kill ""only when justified."" This as the military is investigating two incidents in which allegedly killed Iraqi civilians.
The first incident, which left 24 Iraqis dead in the town Haditha, happened in November.
The second occurred in April in a town west of Baghdad.
NPR's Pentagon correspondent, Tom Bowman, joins us now to talk about all of this.
And Tom, before we get to the details on that second incident, what can you tell us about the Marine Corps' top general, who flew to Iraq today?
Well, General Hagge, what he's gonna try to do over there is make sure the Marines remember the core values of honor, courage and commitment.
And also, he's gonna visit most of the Marines in their forward operating bases west of Baghdad, in Al Anbar Province.

And he's also gonna tell them that the most difficult part of courage is not their physical courage on the battlefield, but rather the moral courage to do the right thing, even under pressure from fellow Marines.
And Tom, now about that second incident in that town west of Baghdad, what more can you tell us about that?

Well, a government official knowledgeable of the investigation said that seven Marines and a Navy Medical Corps member, who's essentially a medic, went on a patrol on April 26 looking for a suspected insurgent.
Now, they didn't find this insurgent at his home, so they went to another house, apparently at random, and they burst into the house and took away an Iraqi male.
They questioned him and then investigators say they shot and killed him.
How did the investigation begin?
Well, the family of the man came forward, talked to military authorities, and then they started an investigation by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service.
And interestingly, what the investigation has found is, not only did they allegedly kill this man, but they also planted evidence to look like he was an insurgent.
They left next to his body a shovel and also an AK-47, so again, he would look like he was an insurgent.
Where are the Marines that were involve din that alleged incident now?
They're all back at their base, Camp Pendleton in California.
We're not sure of their status, if they've been restricted to base or in the brig.
We don't have any information on that, but we know they're all back at Camp Pendleton.
The supply chain didn't always work like this.
Sue Helper says that decades ago, a lot of work like this would have been done close together in the U.S.
And the process could shift in the future, but experts say these tariffs are not likely to bring those wire bundling jobs back to the U.S.
Instead they might push them overseas to other places with low labor costs.
Ann Wilson is with the Motor & Equipment Manufacturers Association.
Keep in mind the wire that goes into those wire harnesses, the fabric that is coated around those wires as well as all of the connectors are oftentimes made in the United States.
So if we make it more expensive to make wire harnesses in Mexico and they move that offshore someplace else, we are going to lose those jobs in the United States.
That's probably a long-term concern.
In the short term, Brad Kraft says he can't just pick up and move his factory from Juarez.
He's only got a week of warning and no way of knowing how long these tariffs would last.
So there's very little that we can do.
Just one thing, really - prepare to pay the tariff and raise prices as a result, a change which would be felt by U.S.
consumers.
Camila Domonoske, NPR News.
I'm Farai Chideya, and this is News & Notes.
If you're a blogger, right now, you're probably in your happy place.
What to talk about next?
The presidential race, legends of black music, or the latest cultural controversies?
We've got plenty on all these fronts on our bloggers round table.

With us, pop culture critic Desmond Burton of the blog Afronerd, Baratunde Thurston, he's a blogger for sites including the Huffington Post, and Carmen Dixon, she writes the blog for All About Race and also the blogs for AOL Black Voices.
Hey, folks, good morning.
Good morning.
Hey, Farai.
Hello.
So, as we've been saying, Obama has pretty much locked up the nomination, and this is a historic election.
So, Baratunde, let me start with you.
What did you know, and when did you know it?
Meaning, how closely did you watch things unfold and watch the speeches, and how did you feel?
I feel great!
I feel like yes, we can became yes, we did.
And at least phase one of this operation to get someone of Obama's caliber and background into the White House.
I've followed everything.
I've watched all the speeches.
I was thrilled to see McCain's speech cut off by the networks, and I think that was a metaphor that McCain's time is up, and Obama and our time is now for the entire season that we're entering.
Carmen, what about you?
How did - you know, on an emotional level?
Well, I have mixed emotions.
I'm thrilled about his success, but the post that I'm writing right now is called, ""Happy, Excited, Dread."" Dread meaning that we have a lot of work to do to get him elected.
He is my candidate.
I am supporting Barack Obama.

But I know the kind of work that it's going to take on the ground and having one-on-one conversations and moving people's opinions to even consider voting for him because I know a lot of people are not even considering it right now.
Desmond, what are you hearing?
Tell us your thoughts on this historic moment, but also, what are you hearing about - whether it's challenges in the upcoming general election, dislike of any candidates from different voters.
What's your ear to the ground?
Well, I guess it's the inevitability of that entire factor.
One major thing, I think, is Hillary Clinton's reaction to the whole thing.
Her disingenuous demeanor.
(Unintelligible)
Well, it's a reality.
It seems like she just didn't want to be gracious about it.
You were able to see just how presidential Obama came across in his delivery, and he was so deferential to her.
And yet, she could not reciprocate that.
So I think what's really being talked about is will he choose her as a VP.
Should he choose her as a VP?
Maybe he's going to be - she's going to wedge herself into that.
My own personal preference would probably be Bloomberg as a bulletproof vest of sorts.
That's like an inside joke to some of my Jewish colleagues.
But, again, I think that there's a lot of work to be done, as Carmen has referenced.
There's a lot of work to go forward.
And I think there's going to be some problems.
And hopefully - honestly...
Are you saying that all black females...
Bobby Kennedy also.
That scared me a little bit.
And I think that, you know, speaking of presidential, what amazed me is that, this morning, President Bush congratulated Senator Obama on clinching the nomination.
Yet, candidate Clinton couldn't do the same.
And you know it's a dark day when a Bush has got a better grip on reality than a Clinton.
Yeah.
Well, Carmen, you know, I saw you making a face when it came up whether or not there will be an Obama/Clinton ticket.
There have been a lot of discussion about whether or not it would be a pro or a con, and Former President Jimmy Carter says no, bad idea.
What do you think?
Well, I think at the heart of it, it's simple.
She can't be on the ticket because Obama is about change.
And if he's true, and if he's going to stay true to his message, to his brand, bringing on Hillary Clinton is not about change.
It's about more of the same.
That's what he campaigned on this entire season.
So to make a U-turn on that, it would certainly alienate me.

Well, Baratunde, though, what about the idea that it is change but too much change, in a country that has historically been governed by white men since day one, at the executive branch level, to have both a black man and a white woman on the same ticket.
Would that kind of, you know, kill any chances for most of the white male vote?
I think that's really a secondary issue.
And in many cases, both Obama and Clinton have transcended their demographics.
They are super strong and powerful brands.
And there are reasons well beyond her being a white female that Clinton represents a pretty bad choice for him.
The behavior of her and her campaign throughout this season has crossed several lines of, you know, difficult to impossible to forgive.
Yes.
Well, in this case, there were, they're looking at a Sergeant and a Corporal and perhaps three other Lance Corporals involved in the deaths of 24 Iraqi civilians, including 11 women and children.
That investigation is ongoing and we expect that to be resolved sometime next month.
Thank you, Tom.
